title: Robert Granger
text:
Robert (Rob) is a PhD student in the Department of Statistics at Indiana University. He has worked on several research projects in application areas like social media, health safety, music, and human rights involving statistical techniques such as generalized/mixed effect regression, state space modeling, capture-recapture, and Bayesian approaches.
In 2012, Rob earned his Bachelor’s degree from Indiana University with majors in Economics, Mathematics, and Political Science and a minor in Religious Studies. Two years later, he earned his Master’s Degree in Economics and began tutoring college students professionally in the subjects of economics and statistics. In 2017, he joined the Master of Statistical Science Program (MSSS) at Indiana University and then in 2019 was accepted into the Statistics PhD program. Currently, he has completed all qualification exams and course requirements. He was recently hired on at Indiana University as a Visiting Lecturer where he teaches up to three sections (~100 students per class) of Business Statistics per semester. He is in the process of drafting a thesis proposal and selecting a thesis committee. He expects to earn his PhD degree in the Spring of 2024.
In his spare time, Rob enjoys spending time with his wife, Mary, and his 21 month old son, Theodore.

title: Research
text:
Exploring the capture-recapture problem with observed and unobserved heterogeneity.
Bayesian, MCMC, data imputation
This research is taking place under the guidance of Professor Daniel Manrique-Vallier.
Expected Proposal Date: March 2023!

Switching State Space Models for Interpreting Musical Dynamics

Switching State Space Models for Interpreting Musical Dynamics - draft
Work in progress used for my data analysis qualifying exam (2020).
This research took place under the guidance of Professor Daniel McDonald.

title: Statistical Literacy: STAT-S100
text: STAT-S 100 Statistical Literacy (3 cr.) CASE N&M P: MATH-M 014 or equivalent. How to be an informed consumer of statistical analysis. Experiments and observational studies, summarizing and displaying data, relationships between variables, quantifying uncertainty, drawing statistical inferences.

title: Statistics for Journalists: STAT-S211
text: STAT-S 211 Statistics for Journalists (3 cr.) CASE N&M P: MATH-M 014 or equivalent. Essential statistical concepts and tools for journalists in the age of data, including probability, graphics, descriptive statistics, prediction, study design, comparison, testing, and estimation. The course has a heavier emphasis on writing and reading media reports than other introductory statistics courses.

title: Introduction to Business Statistics: STAT-S301
text: STAT-S 301 Applied Statistical Methods for Business (3 cr.) CASE N&M P: MATH-M 118 or equivalent. Introduction to methods for analyzing data arising in business, designed to prepare business students for the Kelley School’s Integrative Core. Graphical and numerical descriptions of data, probability models, fundamental principles of estimation and hypothesis testing, applications to linear regression and quality control. Microsoft Excel used to perform analyses.

title: Introduction to Macroeconomics: ECON-E201
text: A descriptive and analytical study of fundamental concepts of national economics. It includes an analysis of the determination and fluctuations in national income and employment, monetary and fiscal policy, and international trade and finance. Economic analysis of monetary and fiscal policies is stressed.

title: Introduction to Microeconomics: ECON-E202
text: A descriptive and analytical study of the market economy and how it allocates resources. Emphasis is placed on consumer behavior, market structure, pricing, and distribution and determination of wealth and income.
